docs.lead_paragraph: Smog and other forms of air pollution appear to have long-term effects on children's lungs and could be a contributing cause of asthma, according to preliminary results of a study released last week. The study, conducted in Southern California, sometimes called the nation's smog capital, found that pollution affects the breathing of girls more than it does boys, even though girls spend less time outdoors than boys.

headline.main: Air Pollution's Havoc on a Child's Lungs

docs.abstract: Preliminary results of study conducted in Southern California show that smog and other forms of air pollution appear to have long-term effects on children's lungs and could be contributing cause of asthma (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Parents, therapists and police officers who give hearsay testimony in court about young children's statements may not be reliable witnesses, according to a new study. The study, which appears this month in The Journal of Experimental Psychology, found that although adults usually can recall the gist of a conversation they have had with a child, they have difficulty remembering the exact wording or the structure of the conversation. They are also likely to remember incorrectly whether information was offered spontaneously by the child or elicited through questions, and to confuse specific statements they made themselves with statements made by the child.

headline.main: Hazy Memories of Chats With Children

docs.abstract: New study finds that parents, therapists and police officers who give hearsay testimony in court about young children's statements may not be reliable witnesses (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Parental concerns about the messages small children receive in G-rated animated feature films have resulted in a review showing that two-thirds of such movies produced over the last 60 years include the use of tobacco and alcohol by villains and heroes alike. Dr. Adam O. Goldstein and his colleagues at the University of North Carolina School of Medicine screened 50 animated feature films by five major production companies, beginning with ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs,'' released in 1937, in which only a poisoned apple was consumed. They found that 34 films had at least one scene in which tobacco or alcohol was used and that the depictions did not decrease over the years.
docs.abstract: Parental concerns about messages small children receive in G-rated animated feature films result in review showing that two-thirds of such movies produced over last 60 years include use of tobacco and alcohol by villains and heroes alike (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A generation ago, Dr. Ancel Keys and colleagues at the University of Minnesota published findings that, if heeded then, would have extended millions of American lives during the last 30 years and millions more in the years to come. The researchers examined the relationship between diet and heart disease rates in seven countries and found that people who lived along the Mediterranean Sea suffered only a tiny fraction of the heart attacks and coronary deaths experienced by Americans and people in other Western industrialized countries. Among people along the Mediterranean, dietary fat consumed was mostly of vegetable origin; among the others, diets were rich in highly saturated animal fats from meat and dairy products.

headline.main: Savory Diet That's Good For Heart? Let's Eat

docs.lead_paragraph: They are pretty poisons. Sweet, pretty with their yellow-green glow and all around us, as common as cars, in homes and garages everywhere. Each year, at least 6,000 Americans, by design or accident, fall victim to poisonings with ethylene glycol, a main ingredient in automotive antifreeze and other products. Unless immediately treated, consumption of this chemical can lead to permanent disability or death.

headline.main: Antidote for Pretty Poison Is Found, but at Big Price

docs.lead_paragraph: Interstate 95 runs along the Eastern Seaboard linking rural Maine to Florida, enabling people and commerce to travel north to south. But in one area, epidemiologists believe the highway may also be a pipeline for syphilis. According to a study by researchers at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the University of Pittsburgh, who examined a decade's syphilis reports in North Carolina counties, the disease appeared more than twice as often in North Carolina rural counties bordering I-95 as it did in rural counties that did not border the highway. The results appear in the current issue of The American Journal of Public Health.

headline.main: The Road to Florida, Maine and Syphilis

docs.abstract: Study of syphilis in North Carolina finds that disease appears more than twice as often in rural communities bordering I-95 as it does in rural counties that do not border highway; map (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors and health officials have long been eager to determine which doctors are most likely to be sued for malpractice. Some studies have suggested that bedside manner is the most effective tool for preventing litigation; other experts have found that lawsuits do not seem to be linked to actual incompetence. Now scientists have added a new piece of data to the puzzle of medical litigation. According to University of Iowa researchers, family doctors with the most impressive credentials were most likely to be sued.

headline.main: A Big Challenge to Skilled Doctors

docs.abstract: University of Iowa researchers find that family doctors with the most impressive credentials are most likely to be sued for malpractice (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Some years ago, well before I got engaged, I had a conversation with a young gastroenterologist about marriage. I was readying myself for medical school and concerned I would not meet anyone outside of medicine. I was certain I did not want to marry a doctor. ''No, marry a doctor,'' the fellow advised. ''When you get paged away during your anniversary dinner, only another doctor will understand.'' Recently, as a newly minted doctor, I got engaged to a medical student. Although we have common interests that extend far beyond medicine, most of my friends focus on the fact that we will both be doctors. Like the gastroenterologist, some think being in the same demanding field will help our marriage. Others think I was bound to marry a doctor, given my schedule, but wonder how we will find time to spend together. A few wink and joke about our future income.
docs.abstract: Essay by Dr Sandeep Jauhar on marriages in which both partners are doctors, in light of fact that she recently became engaged to a doctor; notes that today, many young doctors are marrying other doctors, as there are increasing number of women doctors, about 50 percent of whom have always married other doctors; researchers report in Annals of Internal Medicine that over all, dual-doctor marriages are relatively happy and stable; find that compared with other physicians, doctors in dual-doctor marriages report greater satistfaction in discussing and sharing work interests with their spouses, more involvement in child rearing by both partners and higher family income (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two new studies lend support to the view that by the time children enter elementary school they may have eating and other health habits that will play a major role in the problems they may suffer in later life, including heart disease, high blood pressure and possibly diabetes. Health experts said the findings suggested that it was never too soon to teach children good dietary habits, as well the importance of exercise. This is especially true for black and Mexican-American children. As early as age 6, one of the studies found, they show significant health differences, over all, in comparison with non-Hispanic white children.

headline.main: Early Eating Habits Tied to Adult Ills

docs.abstract: Two new studies lend support to view that by time children enter elementary school they may have eating and other health habits that will play a major role in problems they suffer in later life, including heart disease, high blood pressure and possibly diabetes; suggest that it is never too soon to teach children good dietary habits, as well as importance of exercise; this is especially true for black and Mexican-American children; one of studies shows that as early as age 6, they show significant health differences, over all, in comparison with non-Hispanic white children (M)
